skill.name: biopython
skill.description: Primary Python toolkit for molecular biology. Preferred for Python-based PubMed/NCBI queries (Bio.Entrez), sequence manipulation, file parsing (FASTA, GenBank, FASTQ, PDB), advanced BLAST workflows, structures, phylogenetics. For quick BLAST, use gget. For direct REST API, use pubmed-database.
skill.summary: Primary Python toolkit for molecular biology. Preferred for Python-based PubMed/NCBI queries (Bio.En...
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: The skill is documentation with example code. Examples show network access to NCBI, external command wrappers, and local file I/O. No executable scripts or obfuscation are present.

content.user_title: Learn Biopython workflows for molecular biology
content.value_statement: Bioinformatics tasks can be complex and error prone. This skill gives clear Biopython patterns for sequences, databases, BLAST, structures, and trees.
actual_capabilities: Parse, write, and convert sequence files with Bio.SeqIO
Run pairwise and multiple alignments with Bio.Align and Bio.AlignIO
Query NCBI databases with Bio.Entrez and parse results
Submit BLAST searches with NCBIWWW and parse NCBIXML output
Work with PDB structures using Bio.PDB parsers and analyses
Build and inspect phylogenetic trees with Bio.Phylo
limitations: Examples require Biopython and dependencies installed in your environment
NCBI queries and BLAST require network access and a valid Entrez.email
Local BLAST and external aligners require separate command line tools
This skill provides guidance only and does not execute code

use_cases.title: Learn sequence file basics
use_cases.description: Parse FASTA or GenBank files and understand key Bio.SeqIO patterns.

use_cases.title: Automate NCBI lookups
use_cases.description: Search PubMed or GenBank with Entrez and fetch records for analysis.

use_cases.title: Build BLAST pipelines
use_cases.description: Run BLAST searches and parse results into downstream workflows.

prompt_templates.title: Parse a FASTA file
prompt_templates.prompt: Show how to read a FASTA file with Bio.SeqIO and print each record id and length.

prompt_templates.title: Convert file formats
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide Biopython code to convert a GenBank file to FASTA using SeqIO.convert.

prompt_templates.title: Query NCBI Entrez
prompt_templates.prompt: Give a pattern to search PubMed with Entrez.esearch and fetch the first record.

prompt_templates.title: BLAST and parse hits
prompt_templates.prompt: Draft a workflow to run NCBIWWW.qblast and parse top hits with NCBIXML.

output_examples.input: Summarize steps to fetch a GenBank record by accession with Biopython.
output: Call Entrez.efetch with db nucleotide and the accession
Read the handle with SeqIO.read and close the handle
Print description and sequence length for a quick check

best_practices: Set Entrez.email and respect NCBI rate limits
Use iterators for large files to avoid high memory use
Validate file formats before parsing and handle errors
anti_patterns: Running external command wrappers without installed tools
Submitting high volume NCBI requests without rate control
Loading entire large sequence files into memory

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes. The guidance is platform agnostic and works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code.

faq.question: What are the main limits of this skill?
faq.answer: It provides documentation and examples but does not run code or supply external tools.

faq.question: Can it integrate with local BLAST or aligners?
faq.answer: Yes, it documents Biopython command line wrappers if you install those tools.

faq.question: Does it send my data anywhere by itself?
faq.answer: No. Network calls only occur if you execute the Entrez or BLAST examples.

faq.question: What if Entrez calls fail or return errors?
faq.answer: Check accessions, set Entrez.email, and slow requests to meet NCBI limits.

faq.question: How does this compare to direct REST APIs?
faq.answer: This focuses on Biopython workflows. Use a REST client if you prefer raw API calls.
